ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course has a lot of potential, but turned out to be a huge disappointment. Unfortunately, it's poorly structured and taught. The workload is unusually heavy, but the assignments bear little relevance to the final deliverable of the course which is your own research proposal. To make matter worse, the professor does not provide you with PDFs of her weekly lectures, but will instead post her lectures in Prezzi format which is extremely hard to view and analyze without getting a headache.Bottom line: do yourself a favor, and stay away from this course unless you want to become a frustrated student and waste your time at FES. Now, you should check out the Natural Science Research Methods course, since that instructor gets better reviews from students. And don't worry about the title "Natural Science", you can still take it even if your research is going to deal more with the social sciences. Good luck.
Presentations in Prezi were effective as teaching tools; however it would bbe nice to have the ability to save them asfiles for reference later.

The assignments for this class were particularly relevant and helpful. I think the pace of the course could maybe have been sped up a bit (?) to give more time for students to work on their proposals at the end?

Some information on how to do qualitative research but very little on how to actually apply it. Most info could have been gained from simply reading and doing personal studies. A pretty shallow course overall
This course didn't really fit with my needs, but it was somewhat useful nevertheless.

I though the teacher did an good job of looking things up and responding to student questions. I did notlike how she did not seem especially engaged during our student presentations and gave no written (and pretty much no verbal) feedback. Given the amount of work that goes into a presentation I would have appreciated getting some feedback on what could be improved.She seemed distracted this semester and not particularly excited about the subject matter.

I felt like this class had great potential but that it didn't quite get there. That said, it's an incredibly large, sweeping topic with a classroom full of a variety of research backgrounds. I think the students who found the class the most helpful were MEMs who had never done research before but that is not who the class should be directed towards. The class should be aimed at MESc students with a couple years research experience. I fall into that category and often felt like precious classroom time was spent talking about basic level research methods or justifying why qualitative methodologies are legitimate. I felt like my time (and required course credits) could have been used in a better way.I've thought hard about how this could be improved because as the only required course for MESc students, it is an important class. Perhaps what could be useful is breaking the class into multiple courses, grouping novice researchers together separate from intermediate ones. This, of course, would drastically the Professor's workload and time spent on the course, which may not be of interest.This all said, Professor Doolittle was thoughtful, considerate and engaged with the entire course. It is obviously an incredibly difficult (but important) course to teach, and she should be commended for her efforts.

The course meets it's goals just fine. There is a need for additional research methods courses that cover additional topics. Also, given the number of students in the course, the school should consider additional course options and support.

This class is very useful to start writing a proposal and learning about research methods for use in your own study. The breadth of techniques taught is useful to help with selecting what kinds of methods might be most useful for the student's work.

I didn't purchase the textbook (which was required) and was fine without it. Amity's in-class presentation were EXTREMELY useful and provided all the information I needed. I also referred to them outside class very often. I was skeptical about taking the class but it was a requirement. It turned out to be super helpful. Of course, it was not as "interesting" or theory-based as other classes but in terms of teaching me how to write a proposal and carry our research, it was excellent. I feel very prepared (but will see how it goes!).

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: There are not best aspects to this course, since it leaves a lot to be desired.
I enjoyed the logical progression of skills and how they mapped to the research proposal we were building towards for the end of the course.

I felt the best aspects of the course were learning all the different methods for social science data collection, and actually going out and trying out some of them and learning the challenges of doing each. I also felt the collaboration and discussions in class that allowed students to discuss their research and get feedback was helpful (presentations) although I felt there could have been more of this.
A lot of useful research tools
Gaining basic knowledge in doing research
The assignments were a great opportunity to experiment with different social science methods, and get me a good idea of the different tools research have available.
Class discussions and brain storming
It prepared youto submit a research proposal.
The flexible discussions& amity's exceptional commitment to helping students. It was really impressive.

I liked the instructor's presentations. I wish she had shared her personal experiences more, as she has done fascinating things and I really liked hearing her perspectives on things.Some of the readings were excellent.
Class discussions
The breadth of social science research topics covered
Having students come in and talk about their experiences was super helpful. Wish they weren't so late all the time though.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Everything needs improvement in this course.
The Thursday discussion sections are a good idea but could use some work to be more valuable and more tied in to class topics.

As I mentioned above, I think it would have been good to incorporate a bit more of students individual projects and evaluating those projects (as peers) as the course progressed. There were a couple projects I saw presented at the end that I felt probably still have a long way to go, and it might have been helpful for them to get feedback like this earlier than the end of the semester.
A practical training on some of the research tools.
The survey section of the course is weak, but justifiably so since it is a course on qualitative methods. However, F&ES does not over survey training in any other course.
See question 14

While most of the readings were great, I did not find the Maxwell book particularly useful, especially given that it was the only book we were required to purchase. It was more theoretical and vague than other qualitative methods books that I have used in the past.
would like to have covered more topics and discuss our specific topics more often.
A lot of the assignments and readings were not really all that useful for my particular proposal, perhaps they were useful for some of the students in the class, but definitely not all.

We needed more feedback from the presentations and final projects at the end of the course. We put in an immense amount of work in to the final projects and presentations and I have received no feedback from students of the instructor. What's the point of it all? There is some value in the exercise of working hard, but without feedback a great opportunity for growth is lost. I am really surprised at how little we were able to work on our research topics/ideas in a collaborative fashion. Have the proposals due three weeks earlier, skip the presentations, and have us all spend the time critiquing each other's work.Also, rescheduling the last week of presentations to coincide with finals meant that I couldn't make many of my classmates' presentations. I wanted to be there but there was a scheduling conflict. This was not acceptable, as the entire purpose of the school scheduling the finals is that they can avoid conflicts.

The presumed audience and their expected research experience should be clarified. The assignments at times seemed to be more of a gesture towards research than actual assignments.One can't teach all of anthropology background, theory and methodology in one class to get students up to speed to do acceptable qualitative research. If students are really at the level where they do not know anything about anthropology (or social science) theory and general methodology, they should not be in the same methods course as students who have had years of in-field research experience.

Clarity. Instructor and coursework were not always clear/directly related to people working on their own projects. Students might have benefited more from working together in groups to discuss and improve each other's research based on what each of them is doing and what methods might be best for their studies.

More encouragement on applying to outside grants (not just internal Yale ones). I would have liked to see more concrete examples of others' research: sample proposals, more past FES student budgets, samples of their survey questions, etc.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA
NA
it was good

It was somewhat effective. I thought the small group discussions worked well, but the larger, class discussions were a little crowded feeling. Many of the best times in class were in small groups discussing aspects of readings.
Course lectures and class discussions and activities were well aligned
n/a

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: NA.
I enjoyed the class immensely as a way to learn about methods I have heard of (coding, historical documents, etc.) as well as have an academic approach to various types of social science thinking.

As an MESc this course is very relevant. Social science data collection is an important part of the research I will be doing next summer, and these skills are not only important for my master's research but also for my career.
It's important to support my research
To work on parts of my thesis
I was hoping to gain some familiarity with qualitative research methods as I hope to factor qualitative methods into my future research or career.
This is required for my quantitative research thesis.
I hope to get funding to do a research project this summer, and so this class was very helpful in preparing me to apply for grants.

I hope to do research. However, as someone who hasn't yet conducted research, I don't yet know what I need to study, hence the reason I am in graduate school. I feel like now I should have also taken natural science research methods, though there was no way to know this before beginning the term. There should be a combined course, as it now looks like my research (and a great deal of student research) is not confined to a dichotomy of "natural science" or "social science."
I intend to do research.
Course was great for learning research methods and deciding what I would use for my work.
It is really, really critical to my future research. Cannot stress enough how helpful it is if you do actual research project.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was ill advised to take it.
See above answer in #17.
To give me the basic knowledge for my research
To learn how to conduct research

I used this course for structure in writing my literature review and methods sections from previous research, but also to reflect on what I could have done differently and to think about future research. This course was a great choice, and I hope future 2nd year students will be able to be part of this course in the future. However, the sustainability of such a system should be questioned. That so many 2nd year students took this course after doing research speaks to the inadequacy/poor timing of methods courses at F&ES. This could be partially addressed by helping F&ES students find methods courses in other departments of the university, as they are sometimes difficult to spot.
To gain an understanding of qualitative research methods and how qualitative research can be applied.
I have a better understanding of quantitative research and wanted to learn more about qualitative methods.
See question 17
It was required.
Because I wanted to learn about conducting research. Also, it is a requirement for the MESc program.
It is a degree-required course.
Requirement
To learn about different qualitative research methods
Requirement

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Of course not. This course was immensely frustrating and a big waste of time and money.
Yes.
Yes
Yes, very helpful
Yes, for the most part, but surveys and random sampling are inadequately addressed at F&eS.
No

Yes. But it would have been nice to also include lectures that would help us create a plausible budget for our proposals. I think the school should also offer a quantitative social science course (surveys).

I don't think I learnt all that much (as I have a fairly extensive background in grant writing), but the class got me rolling on my proposal and so I feel good about applying for grants next semester.

Not really. Part of this is that I had unrealistic expectations about how simple research is. Another part is that we didn't spend enough time working on and giving feedback about our respective research projects.
They did not meet my expectations (as explained in earlier responses).
Yes, I learned about social science methods and research approaches that were new to me.
YEs
Yes. Very much. I learned a lot of very practical skills.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA
Good for discussing our research topic and get feedbacks from others
I would have liked to do more of the breakout sessions (like the ones we did in the beginning of the semester) throughout the entire semester.

The group work yielded some great discussions about course content and our research ideas. It was some of the best parts of the class.Some of the group work felt very rushed, in that there were too many people who had to get their ideas across. Everything felt very introductory, in this sense.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Simply don't take it. Do yourself a favor and stay away from it.

Stay up to date with course requirements and remember that the better your work and your deliverables, the more you will help yourself - in learning, for the final proposal paper, and ultimately for your thesis.

My advice is to dive in to the assignments, especially the ones that involve field time (participant observation, etc). In this course, I think doing is the best way to learn many of these methods, so the assignments were very helpful in this sense. That and ask a lot of questions. Amity has a ton of experience and so do your peers, so if you're unsure of how to go about doing something bring it up! There is a lot of good knowledge and experience out there to feed specific questions you may be wondering about.
Take the course before conducting a social research
What you might get out of the class is really up to your motivation

If you plan to do research that involves people - no matter if it is more closely related to conservation biology or the 'natural sciences' - this course is a better selection than the other methods course.
Don't expect much beyond a cursory review of qualitative methods. It will, however, force you to think more about your own research project and how you're going to conduct it.
Try to hone in and pick a research topic as early on in the semester as possible, so that as you complete assignments, the word is leading into your final research.
Amity Doolittle is extremely approachable and very helpful!!
The course is good to help you get a head start on writing your proposal, but don't expect to be riveted by the coursework or lectures.
It really depends on what stage your research is at.

Look carefully at what you want from a research methods course and make sure this is the one you want. To parse out "qualitative" research from quantitive research is to make a somewhat artificial division, so you may feel like a lot is left out.
Keep on your research for your proposal all semester, from day one.
Don't put off proposal until the last minute, especially if is something that interests you. Stay on top of the work, though this is not difficult.
Don't buy the textbook. Put actual thought into the weekly assignments. Choose a topic that interests you.
